H0.text: The inner core is the part of Earth's structure that exists in the solid phase due to low temperatures.

H1.text: The outer core is the part of Earth's structure that exists in the solid phase due to low temperatures.

H2.text: The lithosphere is the part of Earth's structure that exists in the solid phase due to low temperatures.

H3.text: The asthenosphere is the part of Earth's structure that remains solid due to low temperatures.

A4.text: The inner core is solid at high temperature because of its high pressure, in accordance with the Simon-Glatzel equation.

A5.text: The temperature at the surface of the inner core is estimated to be approximately 5,700 K (5,430 째C; 9,800 째F), about the temperature at the surface of the Sun.

A6.text: The asthenosphere is almost solid, but a slight amount of melting (less than 0.1% of the rock) contributes to its mechanical weakness.

A7.text: The lithosphere-asthenosphere boundary is conventionally taken at the 1,300 째C (2,370 째F) isotherm.

A8.text: The outer core is liquid, unlike its inner core, which is solid.
